rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you. See [[WP:FIXNF]] and [[WP:10CR]]
rev.diff:
Line 43: Line 43:
Annie Creek and Sun Creek are extremely important because of the relative rarity of water and [[riparian zone|riparian habitat]] in the area. Both creeks are classified as a large, fish-bearing stream under provisions of [[Oregon Forest Practices Act]]. This reserves sufficient stream flow to support aquatic life, but does not override the most senior [[water rights]].<ref name="JEB"/>
Annie Creek and Sun Creek are extremely important because of the relative rarity of water and [[riparian zone|riparian habitat]] in the area. Both creeks are classified as a large, fish-bearing stream under provisions of [[Oregon Forest Practices Act]]. This reserves sufficient stream flow to support aquatic life, but does not override the most senior [[water rights]].<ref name="JEB"/>
â
[[Image:Wood River 02.png|right|thumb|Restored Wood River Wetland near Agency Lake]]
 
In addition to the fish habitat, the Wood River Valley supports a diverse population of nesting [[ducks]], [[shorebirds]], and migratory [[songbirds]]. These include [[wood duck]]s, [[mallard]]s, [[cinnamon teal]], [[Canadian geese]], [[merganser]]s, [[American coot]]s, [[common snipe]]s, [[mourning dove]]s, [[killdeer]], [[great egret]]s, [[meadowlark]]s, and [[yellow warbler]]s. The area also supports nesting populations of [[bald eagle]]s, [[osprey]]s, and [[northern harrier]]s.<ref name="BLM">[http://www.blm.gov/or/resources/recreation/files/brochures/Wood%20River%20Wetland.pdf ''Wood River Wetland''], Lakeview District, Bureau of Land Management, United States Department of Interior, Lakeview, Oregon, 7 June 2008.</ref>
In addition to the fish habitat, the Wood River Valley supports a diverse population of nesting [[ducks]], [[shorebirds]], and migratory [[songbirds]]. These include [[wood duck]]s, [[mallard]]s, [[cinnamon teal]], [[Canadian geese]], [[merganser]]s, [[American coot]]s, [[common snipe]]s, [[mourning dove]]s, [[killdeer]], [[great egret]]s, [[meadowlark]]s, and [[yellow warbler]]s. The area also supports nesting populations of [[bald eagle]]s, [[osprey]]s, and [[northern harrier]]s.<ref name="BLM">[http://www.blm.gov/or/resources/recreation/files/brochures/Wood%20River%20Wetland.pdf ''Wood River Wetland''], Lakeview District, Bureau of Land Management, United States Department of Interior, Lakeview, Oregon, 7 June 2008.</ref>
